4 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
19.6 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 19 f√©vrier 2022
This is by far the longest puzzle game I've seen and it even has two DLCs included which I didn't have the patience any more to complete. But it's also a prime example of how more content isn't always better value.

First off, the environments are littered with translucent walls as a gameplay element, which is really ugly, and not-quite-invisible walls above every wall, edge or elevated surface you are not supposed to be able to get across because it would invalidate the puzzles, which is just poor design. Even so, apart from the simplest levels in the very first chapter, there is not a single level where there aren't very obvious ways to circumvent at least half the steps/set pieces you are supposed to take/utilize. Most of the time this wasn't faster than the 'correct' path, because it always took me several attempts to get the angle/direction/velocity just right and while in the beginning it was kind of fun to solve the courses in obviously unintended ways it got really tedious later on when the levels become really large and require several dozen needlessly convoluted and often redundant steps to complete, especially once you need to place specific cubes on each pressure plate rather than just any one of them. Somewhat contradictorily, the very techniques that allow you to skip things in earlier levels (mainly jumping over energy walls without deactivating them, which you are generally not supposed to be able to do), are required in some of the later levels.

On the whole, I would argue the level-design is at the very least inelegant and even borderline incompetent. I rate the game only on the merits of its gameplay elements, but it might bear mentioning that the purpose of the puzzles in-universe was also completely ridiculous and the story itself was cheesy and uninspired, but kind of funny near the end.
 
ashes.ney
0
3 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation amusante
1
Non recommand√©
2.1 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 23 mai 2021
Things Relicta does well:
- Storyline
- Visuals
- Basic puzzle structure
Things Relicta does not do so well:
- Integrating puzzles into storyline
- Cuing the player enough to help them solve puzzles and progress
- Making puzzle gameplay smooth enough for satisfying platforming
- Accurately representing the amount of disk space it will take up in the Steam Store requirements
 
biasedeyes

The game is beautiful, has a decent story and some good puzzles but they can be very long (with no real checkpoint) and tedious.

- –ì–æ–ª–æ–≤–æ–ª–æ–º–∫–∏ —è–≤–Ω–æ —Ä–µ—à–∞—é—Ç—Å—è –Ω–µ —Ç–∞–∫, –∫–∞–∫ –∑–∞–¥—É–º–∞–ª —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—á–∏–∫.
- –ú–µ—Å—Ç–∞–º–∏ —ç—Ç–∞ –∏–≥—Ä–∞ —Ä–µ–Ω–¥–æ–º (–ø–æ–ª–µ—Ç –∫—É–±–∏–∫–∞)
- –≥–≥ –¥–µ—Ä–µ–≤—è–Ω–Ω–∞—è –Ω–∞ –æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ
- –°—é–∂–µ—Ç –±–µ—Å—Ç–æ–ª–∫–æ–≤—ã–π. –ë—É–¥—É—â–∏–µ, –∞ –±–µ–∑–æ–ø–∞—Å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –≤–æ–æ–±—â–µ –Ω–µ—Ç. –ü–æ –∏—Ç–æ–≥—É, –≥–≥ –∑–∞—á–µ–º-—Ç–æ –∏–¥–µ—Ç –∫ —Ü–µ–ª–∏ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–µ—Å—Ç–æ–≤—ã–µ –∫–∞–º–µ—Ä—ã. –ß—Ç–æ? –ó–∞—á–µ–º? –ü—Ä–∏ —á–µ–º —Ç—É—Ç —Å—é–∂–µ—Ç? –≠—Ç–æ –∑–Ω–∞–µ—à—å, –ø—Ä–∏–∫–∏–Ω—å —Å–µ–±–µ —Å–∏—Ç—É–∞—Ü–∏—é: –î–æ–ø—É—Å—Ç–∏–º, –≥–æ—Ä–∏—Ç –∫—Ä–µ—Å–ª–æ. –ù–æ –≤–º–µ—Å—Ç–æ —Ç–æ–≥–æ, —á—Ç–æ–±—ã –∫–∞–∫ –º–∏–Ω–∏–º—É–º –≤–∑—è—Ç—å –æ–≥–Ω–µ—Ç—É—à–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å, –∞ –∫–∞–∫ –º–∞–∫—Å–∏–º—É–º —É–π—Ç–∏ –∏ –≤—ã–∑–≤–∞—Ç—å –ø–æ–∂–∞—Ä–Ω—ã—Ö, —Ç—ã –ø–µ—Ä–µ–≤–æ–¥–∏—à—å –≤–∑–≥–ª—è–¥ –Ω–∞ –∫–æ–Ω—Å–æ–ª—å –∏ —Ç–∞–∫–æ–π "–∞ —á–æ, —Å–∞–º–æ–µ –≤—Ä–µ–º—è –ø–æ–∏–≥—Ä–∞—Ç—å". –í–æ—Ç —Ç–∞–∫–∞—è –∂–µ —Ç—É–ø–æ—Å—Ç—å —Å —Å—é–∂–µ—Ç–æ–º –ø—Ä–æ–∏—Å—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç –≤ —ç—Ç–æ–π –∏–≥—Ä–µ.
 
Sey Angel

2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
16.8 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 25 janvier 2022
I made it to the last section of the game (Jungle) and I have to say, I can't finish it. I am just not interested anymore. I was soldiering on, doing the same kind of puzzle over and over for 15 hours or so and it's just not fun. Compared to Magrunner, I can't often tell if I solved the puzzle right or if I "cheated".

The puzzle mostly is not "figure out how to do X" but "figure where we hid all the pieces.

The envinroments are good, the story I didn't care about, the section where you have to go back and forth through endless corridors to reach the next area is an absolute chore. Problem with the environments being scenic is that it obstructs the puzzle. I like that the game tries to steer away from the clean design a'la Portal or Turing Test but I feel like it is to detriment of the gameplay here. It is always disappointing to hit an invisible wall when you feel like you have the right solution.

It's not a bad game, but it's not very good either - as far as FPS puzzlers go, you can do better and you can do worse.
 
euqil

1,043 produits enregistr√©s
0
3 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
1
Non recommand√©
17.2 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 23 aout 2020
Despite my recommendation, I want to start on a positive note. This game clearly has had a lot of work put into it and I respect that. The environment looks really good and is really well developed, much like the Talos Principle as others say. While the environment design was phenomenal, I can't say the same as much for the puzzles though.

Most of them are fun, but there are some that left an overwhelmingly negative impression in my mind. Now, I enjoy finding the solution that the developers intend. There are a lot of games that you can either abuse mechanics or come up with a different way to solve the same problem, but I just like finding that clean, methodical solution. Early game, there were some puzzles though that it seemed the intended solution was to abuse mechanics. As another reviewer mentioned, in the late game, individual "chambers" - thinking of Portal's idea of testing chambers - were MASSIVE with lots of moving parts. Some may like that, but I'm not a fan. There are two reasons why. First, it becomes very difficult to find the button, cube or whatever you need to either get started to continue working the puzzle. Second, it is VERY easy to soft lock yourself. Yes, you can reset yourself to the beginning of the chamber, but you lose a lot of progress and it takes time to work through a massive puzzle all over again. I'm no stranger to first person puzzle games and if I go back to those same puzzles later I very well may facepalm and realize the solution was right in front of me but I was just being slow. However, the frustration I felt on account of these previously mentioned reasons is why I cannot recommend this game to others.

Now I have some additional criticism, but it's very minor compared to everything above. The story. Moves. Very. Slowly. Late game especially, since at that point I generally only heard dialog every other "chamber." Keep in mind, each "chamber" gets larger and larger, taking more and more time to complete, so it can be a while before you hear even just a single sentence from the character you're playing as. Story isn't that important to me - Rethink didn't have a story at all and I still really enjoyed it - but story progression at slightly faster pace would improve it, in my opinion.

I want to end this review the same way I started - on a positive note. Once again, I appreciate the effort the devs put into this game. The amount of content this game offers is absolutely worth the 20$. I really wish I could recommend it to others because of that. Please do comment if you disagreed with me at any point. A discussion would probably better capture what I really wanted to include in this review anyway.

This review is somewhat a work in progress - I'll be updating it occasionally as I think of better ways to describe what I'm thinking.
 
Michaelsoft Binbows

√âvaluation publi√©e le 16 juillet 2021
Hui & Pfui!

Und wiedermal ist es schade, da√ü es keinen Daumen seitw√§rts gibt.

Da mich die Vorschau an diverse Vorg√§nger der Puzzleszene erinnnerten, habe ich dieses Spiel gekauft. Die R√§tsel f√ºr sich sind, bis auf wenige Ausnahmen, von anf√§nglich leicht bis gegen Ende ziemlich schwierig/langwierig. Ausnahmen bilden dabei die Arten von Puzzles, bei denen es auf die richtige Platzierung der W√ºrfel VOR den Kontakten ankommt. Dort beruht die L√∂sung mehr oder weniger auf dem Zufall, das Rumprobieren nimmt viel Zeit in Anspruch und es baut sich schnell Frust auf. Zum Gl√ºck gibt es davon nur wenige.

Bis hierhin klingt es nach Spa√ü, wenn da nicht die Abschnitte w√§ren, in denen gesprochen wird. Diese verdarben f√ºr mich (fast) das ganze Spiel und ich war heilfroh, wenn ich wieder in den Puzzle-Arealen f√ºr mich allein war. Obwohl auch dort vereinzelt zwischen den Puzzles diverse Dialoge zu h√∂ren waren. Quasi ununterbrochen wird geflucht, geschimpft und beleidigt, was das Zeug h√§lt. F*ck you hier, F*ck you da, A**hole, s*ck, scr*w you, und so weiter und so fort. Ich wei√ü nicht, ob es die Entwickler f√ºr besonders witzig hielten oder was f√ºr Intensionen sie sonst f√ºr diese Orgie an Kraftausdr√ºcken hatten. Mich jedenfalls st√∂rt es extrem und senkt das Niveau des ansonsten sch√∂nen Puzzlespiels.

Wie gesagt, da es keinen Daumen seitw√§rts gibt, von mir einen Daumen hoch, da dieses Genre so selten vertreten und die Puzzles ansich zum Denken anregen.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 11 mai 2021
tries to be portal with gravity instead of portals. It fails to be the same with several aspects, including using the idea of showing new mechanics then implementing them. Most of the levels take luck to beat the first try and fail to achieve the 'i got it moment'. The story is alright but drags a fair amount with a far amount of filler walking to let the story dialogue go, or for no reason.
 
KingOrpheus
1,542 produits enregistr√©s
0
3 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
29.9 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 15 aout 2020
This game is a breath of fresh air. It's very much in the style of puzzle games, and it hits it out of the park on that front. I've had a lot of experience with these types of games, having played Portal, Portal 2, The Talos Principle, The Witness, The Turing Test, Steamroll, Lightmatter, Q.U.B.E, The Swapper, Chromagun, The Spectrum Retreat, MIND: Path to Thalmos, Etherborn, Polarity, and Magrunner: Dark Pulse so I feel like I can speak with some leverage in the this particular niche (which happens to be my favorite!)

You play as a female scientist on a base on the moon. You are trying to get everyone in your crew together but things just don't seem to be going the way you want them to and in order to press forward you have to complete various puzzles. These puzzles typically involve cubes, pressure plates, switches, gravity, anti-gravity and magnetism and you have to use all of them to your advantage to move forward. Early on as the game introduces concepts through puzzles, they easier and quicker to move through. As you progress the puzzles in Relicta become challenging almost, at times, to the point of frustration, but very satisfying to solve and totally reasonable when you realize what you are supposed to do. The breadth of some of the levels makes them take quite a bit of time to both analyze, set up a plan, and implement it. Occasionally the implementation of your ideas does not function right and you have to try repeatedly to accomplish what you want to do (or give up on that method), but the game does a good job of allowing easy ways to get your cubes back as well as an easy way to restart a particular puzzle if you need to. I was particularly impressed with some of the really unique ways that Relicta has you solve parts of puzzles. When I made the discovery of how to do these particular things, it felt so incredible. You have to really think outside the box! Since I would describe this game as a puzzler, I wanted this to be the first thing I discussed.

The graphics of the game are good. Each area of puzzles has it's own beautiful biome style and they are impressive. I was a bit disappointed that I couldn't explore as much as I'd like due to the invisible walls. I particularly liked the jungle biome and I liked the sounds for it too.

The game runs smooth at about 80-100 fps with my GTX 980. I have not had any bugs and the game seems well polished.

The voice acting is good, but I wouldn't call it outstanding.

I was not too happy about all the crude language in this game so, fair warning, you're not going to want to play it around kids at least during the times you are travelling because that's when the dialogue happens. Every game I've played in this style has managed to do it with little to no cussing from what I remember, but this game excessively uses it in my opinion.

The one other gripe I have is with the travelling. Travelling from place to place through the main area and the other world areas was really kind of difficult. Half the time I didn't seem to know exactly where to go and had to just stumble around. It would be nice to have some sort of arrow to direct you where it wants you to go so you can get there - there are just so many ways to go. That said, the game does have hidden PDA notes and some collectibles hidden throughout the worlds, which is nice.

I forget where I made the discovery of Relicta initially, but I am glad I decided to pick it up. Typically I don't buy a game at full price, but I did with this one knowing the style of game it was and I have to say it had totally been worth that amount of money. Based on what I know about the game, I'm guessing I am a little over halfway through it at the time of this review and have put in 12 hours. The story has kept me interested in what is yet to come, and I can't wait to know what the ending is going to be. For very few people working on this game, I am very impressed with the quality of it. It's hard to find a good game in this vein, but this is definitely one of them.
 
catholicbatman
168 produits enregistr√©s
0
3 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
40.3 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 8 juin 2021
Relicta is a first person puzzle game that really wants to be Portal.

Like all such games, it falls well short.

But unfortunately, it doesn‚Äôt even manage to stand out particularly as its own thing. Despite its high graphical fidelity and production quality, it starts out promising but ends up falling apart about halfway through, both in terms of gameplay and story.

Like all such games, it has a ‚Äúcore mechanic‚Äù. The core mechanic here is the ability to give blocks (and some pads that can hold charges) either a red charge or a blue charge. Opposite colored charges attract, same-colored charges repel.

In addition, you can make blocks weightless, allowing them to fly through the air after having been given a push from a charge, or continuing on their momentum from a moving platform.

That‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs all there is.

The game is entirely centered around grabbing blocks and putting them on buttons to get rid of various force fields blocking your way, and sometimes toggling the odd switch. The force fields can either block everything, or only one thing ‚Äì you, blocks, or drones.

There are some platforms that you can move, along with some drones that remove all special effects on all nearby blocks and charge pads, and which can carry blocks.

And‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs all the mechanics there is.

The problem is, this is a 15 hour long game, but it has fewer, and less interesting, mechanics than something like Portal 2.

So how does it make the game last 15 hours?

Unfortunately, the answer to that is by just making increasingly long puzzles in the back half of the game. Frequently, puzzles would either be multi-stage things, where you go through a series of mini-puzzles, or a puzzle where there was some sort of ‚Äúhub‚Äù that you kept on having to solve mini-puzzles to unlock a central door. Only rarely were there big puzzles that actually felt like they integrated all the pieces.

As a result, the entire second half of the game starts to end up feeling tedious rather than interesting. Some of the later game puzzles were okay, but never was there a puzzle in the game where I felt like it was particularly amazing to solve. A lot of the ‚Äúharder‚Äù puzzles were harder because you couldn‚Äôt find a particular ‚Äúpuzzle piece‚Äù, so to speak; once you actually had the pieces in hand, what you were actually supposed to do was often fairly straightforward, if sometimes fiddly later in the game, as you had to line things up rather awkwardly to make some puzzles work, as the ‚Äúsnap-to‚Äù portions didn‚Äôt work in some areas due to them not sending you in quite the right direction or being aligned in the right way.

The game ends up just kind of dragging on by the end, and I just wanted it to be over.

Which brings up the other problem ‚Äì the story.

It starts out promisingly enough ‚Äì there‚Äôs some sort of inciting incident with a weird purple crystal, you have a set of coworkers around and a daughter who is coming to the space station, ect.

The problem is, this all ends up falling apart about halfway through the game. The central plot twist of the game isn‚Äôt very good and results in almost all of the characters you spent the first half of the game talking with never talking to you again throughout the rest of the game. As a result, the game's supporting cast dynamics end up being totally tossed out the window and not mattering at all for the rest of the game, as you end up interacting with a second, and less interesting, set of characters for the second half of the game.

Indeed, if you spend any time thinking about the plot twist, it both feels unnecessarily convoluted and makes no physical sense, nor sense with the other characters in the story, who act like no time has passed at all. The loss of contact with their former colleagues gets short shrift and the story itself seems to forget about what happened to them, as the characters don‚Äôt seem to care despite supposedly being emotionally invested. Only at the very end of one of the game‚Äôs two multiple endings (which are chosen at the last minute for‚Ä¶ some reason? I don‚Äôt even know why it has multiple endings‚Ä¶) does the game remember ‚ÄúOh, these people existed‚Äù and actually follow up on it at all, and then only in a stinger thing that is not very satisfying (though there‚Äôs more from a title update I have yet to play).

Overall, then, the game fails to deliver in terms of story, character, or gameplay. The story doesn‚Äôt even make a ton of sense in terms of characterization, and the gameplay is too simple for a game as long as Relicta is. Despite a potentially promising start, it just doesn‚Äôt hold up, and it never really does anything particularly good, let alone great.
 
TheTitaniumDragon

If you enjoyed puzzle games like Portal, Talos Principle, you'll like this one too. The puzzle difficulty curve was also very well planned out, and there were manymore puzzles than I was expecting for the price! There is a story happening, but it could be better at connecting with the puzzle route.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 6 aout 2020
Einsatzbericht: 5799310 Datum: 06/08/20 Einsatzleiter/in: Dr. Angelica Patel

In den letzten 10-15 Stunden war ich aufgrund verschiedenster teschnicher St√∂rungen gezwungen, in der als Mana III bekannten Basis auf dem Mond in verschiedensten k√ºnstlich generierten Biomen mithilfe der Testobjekte (Gravitationshandschuhe) eine Unmenge an zum teil √§u√üerst schwierigen auf den physikalischen Gesetzen der Gravitation beruhenden R√§tsel zu l√∂sen. Sys hatte w√§hrend besagter Zeit leider einige schwerwiegende Fehlfunktionen, weshalb das vorankommen sich an manchen Stellen als schwierig gestaltet. Zudem musste ich manchmal aufgrund von Sch√§den an einzelnen R√§tseln einen neuen Ansatz suchen, jedoch kann ich nun im Nachhinein sagen, dass der Einsatz ein voller Erfolg war und ich hoffe weitere Feldeins√§tze auf Mana III leiten zu d√ºrfen.

P.S Alami ich z√§hle darauf dass sie wieder mit von der Partie sind.
 
K√∂nig der Gorgone
0
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
17.7 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 17 juillet 2021
Relicta is a beautiful puzzle game that reminded me portal and the talos principle. You are in space in a facility, where inside it there are test rooms that you travel with puzzles and every new room/region have a new concept(jungle, desert etv) There is a story and it's ok, a bit of humor and it tries to get you involved with the other characters (voices only), but never feel the conection. The game have amazing graphics and have stunning landscapes, i found myself just staring at the different enviroments in each room. It took me around 11 hours to finish (100%) the main game, without me trying the new 2 bonus adventures that was added on April.

In the game you are moving some cubes and place them to the correct places so you can proceed, with the help of a glove that gives possitive and negative polarity and gravity. The puzzles are kinda difficult and i would not say that is an easy puzzle game, but it was fun, and when i had a chance to spare 1-2 hours i would open it and play it. In general suggest this game, maybe not full price (not that high tbh), but for sure in sales.

Œ§Œø relicta ŒµŒØŒΩŒ±Œπ Œ≠ŒΩŒ± œÄŒøŒªœç œåŒºŒøœÅœÜŒø œÄŒ±ŒπœáŒΩŒØŒ¥Œπ Œ≥œÅŒØœÜœâŒΩ œÄŒøœÖ Œ∏œÖŒºŒØŒ∂ŒµŒπ ŒªŒØŒ≥Œø ŒºŒØŒæŒ∑ portal Œ∫Œ±Œπ talos principle. ŒíœÅŒØœÉŒ∫ŒµœÉŒ±Œπ œÉœÑŒø Œ¥ŒπŒ¨œÉœÑŒ∑ŒºŒ± ŒºŒ≠œÉŒ± œÉŒµ ŒºŒπŒ± œÄŒµŒπœÅŒ±ŒºŒ±œÑŒπŒ∫ŒÆ ŒµŒ≥Œ∫Œ±œÑŒ¨œÉœÑŒ±œÉŒ∑, œåœÄŒøœÖ ŒµŒΩœÑœåœÇ Œ±œÖœÑŒÆœÇ ŒºŒµœÑŒ±œÜŒ≠œÅŒµœÉŒ±Œπ œÉŒµ ŒΩŒ≠Œ± Œ¥œâŒºŒ¨œÑŒπŒ±-Œ∫œåœÉŒºŒøœÖœÇ œÄŒøœÖ Œ≠œáŒøœÖŒΩ œÜœÑŒπŒ±œáœÑŒµŒØ ŒºŒµ Œ¥ŒπŒ¨œÜŒøœÅŒøœÖœÇ Œ≥œÅŒØœÜŒøœÖœÇ Œ∫Œ±Œπ œåŒªŒø Œ±œÖœÑœå(Œ∫Œ¨Œ∏Œµ œÄŒµœÅŒπŒøœáŒÆ) œÄŒµœÅŒπŒ≤Œ¨ŒªŒªŒµœÑŒ±Œπ Œ±œÄœå Œ≠ŒΩŒ± Œ¥ŒπŒ±œÜŒøœÅŒµœÑŒπŒ∫œå œÑŒøœÄŒØŒø œÄŒøœÖ Œ≠œáŒøœÖŒΩ œÜœÑŒπŒ¨ŒæŒµŒπ(Œ∂ŒøœçŒ≥Œ∫ŒªŒ±, Œ≠œÅŒ∑ŒºŒøœÇ Œ∫œÑŒª). Œ•œÄŒ¨œÅœáŒµŒπ ŒπœÉœÑŒøœÅŒØŒ± Œ∑ ŒøœÄŒøŒØŒ± ŒµŒØŒΩŒ±Œπ œÉœÖŒºœÄŒ±Œ∏Œ∑œÑŒπŒ∫ŒÆ, Œ≠œáŒµŒπ ŒªŒØŒ≥Œø œáŒπŒøœçŒºŒøœÅ, œÄœÅŒøœÉœÄŒ±Œ∏ŒµŒØ Œ∫ŒπœåŒªŒ±œÇ ŒΩŒ± œÉŒµ Œ∫Œ¨ŒΩŒµŒπ ŒΩŒ± Œ¥ŒµŒ∏ŒµŒØœÇ ŒºŒµ œÑŒøœÖœÇ œáŒ±œÅŒ±Œ∫œÑŒÆœÅŒµœÇ (ŒºœåŒΩŒø œÜœâŒΩŒ≠œÇ) Œ±ŒªŒªŒ¨ Œ¥Œµ œÑŒø œÄŒøŒªœç œÄŒµœÑœÖœáŒ±ŒØŒΩŒµŒπ Œ∫Œ±œÑŒ¨ œÑŒ∑ Œ≥ŒΩœéŒºŒ∑ ŒºŒøœÖ. Œ§Œø œÄŒ±ŒπœáŒΩŒØŒ¥Œπ Œ±œÄœå Œ¨œÄŒøœàŒ∑ Œ≥œÅŒ±œÜŒπŒ∫œéŒΩ Œ∫Œ±Œπ œÑŒøœÄŒØœâŒΩ ŒÆœÑŒ±ŒΩ Œ±œÅŒ∫ŒµœÑŒ¨ œåŒºŒøœÅœÜŒø Œ∫Œ±Œπ œÄŒµœÅŒπœÄŒøŒπŒ∑ŒºŒ≠ŒΩŒø Œ∫Œ±Œπ Œ≤œÅŒÆŒ∫Œ± œÑŒøŒΩ ŒµŒ±œÖœÑœå ŒºŒøœÖ Œ±œÄŒªŒ¨ ŒΩŒ± œáŒ±Œ∂Œµœçœâ œÑŒø œÄŒµœÅŒπŒ≤Œ¨ŒªŒªŒøŒΩ œÉœÑŒ± Œ¥œâŒºŒ¨œÑŒπŒ± ŒºŒµ œÑŒøœÖœÇ Œ≥œÅŒØœÜŒøœÖœÇ. ŒúŒøœÖ œÄŒÆœÅŒµ Œ∫Œ¨œÑŒπ ŒªŒπŒ≥œåœÑŒµœÅŒø Œ±œÄœå 11 œéœÅŒµœÇ Œ≥ŒπŒ± ŒΩŒ± Œ≤Œ≥Œ¨Œªœâ 100% œÑŒø main œÄŒ±ŒπœáŒΩŒØŒ¥Œπ œáœâœÅŒØœÇ ŒΩŒ± Œ≠œáœâ Œ±œÉœáŒøŒªŒ∑Œ∏ŒµŒØ ŒºŒµ 2 ŒºœÄœåŒΩŒøœÖœÇ ŒπœÉœÑŒøœÅŒØŒµœÇ ŒºŒµ Œ¨ŒªŒªŒøœÖœÇ œáŒ±œÅŒ±Œ∫œÑŒÆœÅŒµœÇ œåœÄŒøœÖ œÄœÅŒøœÉœÑŒ≠Œ∏Œ∑Œ∫Œ±ŒΩ œÑŒøŒΩ ŒëœÄœÅŒØŒªŒπŒø.

Œ£œÑŒø œÄŒ±ŒπœáŒΩŒØŒ¥Œπ œÉœÑŒ∑ŒΩ ŒøœÖœÉŒØŒ± ŒºŒµœÑŒ±œÜŒ≠œÅŒµŒπœÇ Œ∫œçŒ≤ŒøœÖœÇ Œ∫Œ±Œπ œÑŒøœÄŒøŒ∏ŒµœÑœéŒΩœÑŒ±œÇ œÑŒøœÖœÇ œÉœÑŒ± œÉœâœÉœÑŒ¨ œÉŒ∑ŒºŒµŒØŒ± Œ≠œáŒøŒΩœÑŒ±œÇ œÉŒ±ŒΩ ‚ÄúœåœÄŒªŒø‚Äù Œ≠ŒΩŒ± Œ≥Œ¨ŒΩœÑŒπ œÄŒøœÖ Œ¥ŒØŒΩŒµŒπ ŒµŒØœÑŒµ Œ∏ŒµœÑŒπŒ∫ŒÆ ŒµŒØœÑŒµ Œ±œÅŒΩŒ∑œÑŒπŒ∫ŒÆ œÄŒøŒªŒπŒ∫œåœÑŒ∑œÑŒ± Œ∫Œ±Œπ œÑŒ∑ŒΩ œÑŒ∑ŒΩ ŒπŒ¥ŒπœåœÑŒ∑œÑŒ± œÑŒ∑œÇ Œ≤Œ±œÅœçœÑŒ∑œÑŒ±œÇ. ŒüŒπ Œ≥œÅŒØœÜŒøŒπ ŒºœÄŒøœÅœé ŒΩŒ± œÄœâ œÄœâœÇ ŒµŒØŒΩŒ±Œπ Œ∫Œ¨œÄœâœÇ Œ¥œçœÉŒ∫ŒøŒªŒøŒπ œÉŒµ Œ±œÅŒ∫ŒµœÑŒ¨ œÉŒ∑ŒºŒµŒØŒ± Œ∫Œ±Œπ Œ≥ŒµŒΩŒπŒ∫Œ¨ Œ¥Œµ Œ∏Œ± œÑŒø œáŒ±œÅŒ±Œ∫œÑŒÆœÅŒπŒ∂Œ± œÉœáŒµœÑŒπŒ∫Œ¨ ŒµœçŒ∫ŒøŒªŒø, Œ±ŒªŒªŒ¨ ŒÆœÑŒ±ŒΩ Œ≠ŒΩŒ± œâœÅŒ±ŒØŒø œÄŒ±ŒπœáŒΩŒØŒ¥Œπ, œåœÄŒøœÑŒµ Œ≠Œ≤œÅŒπœÉŒ∫Œ± Œ≠ŒΩŒ± Œ∫ŒµŒΩœå œáœÅœåŒΩŒø 1-2 œâœÅœéŒΩ œÄŒøœÖ ŒºœÄŒøœÅŒøœçœÉŒ± ŒΩŒ± Œ±œÜŒπŒµœÅœéœÉœâ œÉŒµ Œ∫Œ¨œÄŒøŒπŒø œÄŒ±ŒπœáŒΩŒØŒ¥Œπ Œ¥Œµ œÑŒø œÉŒ∫ŒµœÜœÑœåŒºŒøœÖŒΩ Œ∫Œ±Œπ œÑŒø Œ≠œÄŒπŒ±ŒΩŒ±. ŒìŒµŒΩŒπŒ∫Œ¨, ŒÆœÑŒ±ŒΩ Œ≠ŒΩŒ± œÄŒ±ŒπœáŒΩŒØŒ¥Œπ œÄŒøœÖ Œ∏Œ± œÑŒø œÄœÅœåœÑŒµŒπŒΩŒ±, ŒØœÉœâœÇ œåœáŒπ œÉœÑŒ∑ŒΩ Œ∫Œ±ŒΩŒøŒΩŒπŒ∫ŒÆ œÑŒπŒºŒÆ(Œ±ŒΩ Œ∫Œ±Œπ Œ¥ŒµŒΩ ŒµŒØŒΩŒ±Œπ œÄŒøŒªœç œàŒ∑ŒªŒ¨ 20), Œ±ŒªŒªŒ¨ œÉŒØŒ≥ŒøœÖœÅŒ± œÉŒµ Œ≠Œ∫œÄœÑœâœÉŒ∑.
 
yaya14

2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
3.1 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 5 octobre 2023
I had to think about this rating a lot, and in the end I have to say I don't recommend it by a hair's width.

Relicta is a pretty good 3D puzzle game. The obvious comparison is PORTAL, but instead of portals, you have the powers of magnetism & turning gravity on or off. And instead of damaging obstacles, you have like 8 types of barriers. It's not a bad game, but it has two massive, and I mean MASSIVE problems.

1) When you walk into a room, you have to spend several minutes running around trying to figure out where everything is and what your goal even is. There's no clear exit marker or special color for the final barrier you need to deactivate, and the beautiful nature environments actually make this worse because there's a lot of visual clutter. The visual clutter gets progressively worse each area, as a new color of holographic light is added for the new mechanic. And finally, because some of these puzzles have verticality / multiple floors, you literally can't see half the map until you solve half the puzzle, and then go "oh" and have to restart and do something different.

2) The physics simulation(s) and hitboxes are not nice to you. First off, they appear to be locked to framerate (bad), and second, the margin of error allowed in most of these puzzles is super low, way too low: you can do everything right but somehow fall off a box, or get bounced slightly in the wrong direction, bump a ceiling, walk too close to a ledge, etc. and bam! Retry it all! Go set everything up for the solution for another 4 minutes :) There are several puzzles that I've basically completed, only to bump a ceiling somehow, or otherwise get knocked back to the start, repeatedly, for no discernable reason. I think another issue is that, because of the gravity-type repulsive forces, objects tend to move very quickly which seems to make some puzzles much harder than they should be. I don't really know how to explain that the physics of the game just don't feel right. They're too realistic for a puzzle game but not realistic enough for a hyper-realistic sim game.

To conclude, while the puzzles are fun and quite difficult, most of the difficulty actually comes from the game's puzzle setups being annoying and convoluted, as well as the practice of knowing what hitbox jank to avoid. It's a beautiful game, and the mechanics are cool, but I just can't recommend it because it feels like half the game isn't solving puzzles at all, it's just fighting with the game engine or confusedly running through buildings.

Story wise, it's quite good, with the exception that there's zero reason to solve all the puzzles. I don't care if it's a "computer glitch" there's no way literally every inch of this planet has been filled with energy walls and high powered magnets and boxes with no shutoff. Nobody besides the player character even has the ability to do the magnetism thing! This is a futuristic space station and they have -2 contingency plans, so when things go wrong our very intelligent scientist friends just decide to solve the puzzles anyways while people are actively freezing to death.
 
Un d√©veloppeur ou une d√©veloppeuse a r√©pondu √† cette √©valuation

√âvaluation publi√©e le 14 juin 2021
Is a decent puzzle game. But not great.
Graphics are just ok. Music is rare, but fits the game.
Story is serviceable. But dialogs are poorly written.
Puzzles offer a decent challenge. But a several are dependent on physics and sometimes don't work at the first try, nor the second, nor the third. So you have to keep repeating, until the physics engine does what it's supposed to do.

Phenomenal first-person puzzle game. There was some jank flying on boxes, but not enough to deter me from finishing or recommending this game. For what it's worth, the game ran pretty well on my old toaster of a desktop but turned my PC into a space heater, raising the temperature of my office a few degrees in the process.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 22 janvier 2022
Szeretem a puzzle j√°t√©kokat, de egy puzzle j√°t√©k legyen v√°ltozatos. Itt v√©gig h√ºlye kock√°kat kell rakni A-b√≥l B-be. Az igaz hogy az√©rt vannak fejt√∂r≈ë feladatok ( persze szint√©n a kock√°kkal ) de egy eg√©sz j√°t√©kot ezzel t√∂lteni, el√©g unalmas. A l√°tv√°ny sz√©p, tal√°n a story is j√≥ lehet, csak a j√°t√©k menet lehetne sokkal v√°ltozatosabb. Enn√©l vannak jobb / izgalmasabb j√°t√©kok olcs√≥bban is, k√°r erre p√©nzt/energi√°t √°ldozni.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 7 juillet 2021
Sehr sch√∂ner Puzzle-Plattformer mit einer spannenden Story und sehr realistischen Dialogen, die auch alle sehr gut auf Englisch synchronisiert sind. Wundersch√∂ne Umgebung f√ºr ein Puzzle-Spiel.

Ein paar Dinge muss ich jedoch kritisieren:
- Zum einen bietet das Spiel zwar die M√∂glichkeit einen tobii Eyetracker zu verwenden, doch leider funktioniert das nicht so wirklich oder ich mache etwas falsch.
- Die Dialoge sind zwar gut, aber ich h√§tte mir noch ein paar mehr Reaktionen auf die Umgebung gew√ºnscht, wie zum Beispiel auf die zerst√∂rten G√§nge, die zu den Puzzles f√ºhren.
- Nach einigen Stunden Spielzeit l√§uft der RAM √ºber, weil anscheinend die zuvor absolvierten Puzzle noch geladen sind. Ein kurzes Neustarten hilft in so einer Situation.

Kurze Zusammenfassung: Sehr gutes Spiel und auch das Geld wert, k√∂nnte aber noch ein paar Funktions-Updates bekommen.

0
Recommand√©
12.8 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 3 juillet 2021
Decent 1st person puzzle game with some enjoyable spins on mechanic without really breaking any new ground if you have played any of the pillars of the genre. Nice, if shallow, premise that meshes reasonably well with the central conceit that all of these games have to ignore/confront: Why am I doing this set of self-contained puzzles? Interesting characters with good voice acting even if that side is also not explored much. Idea of locations are clever although in execution bit generic space station/forest/desert and a bit too much trudging without anything of note happening. Most of the puzzles are grokkable with a handful of tedious ones that overstay the point where you know what to do but have to wait for timings to align.
 
drgoblin
0
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
35.1 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 13 juin 2021
I typically like puzzle games, but this one doesn't work for me.
The riddles are just tedious. You need to move boxes from A to B pressing buttons to unlock your way or you ride on the boxes to your next riddle. Pretty early on, the levels get too big to have a good overview. You run around a few minutes to figure out the layout, where to get the boxes and where to move them. This just feels completely unnecessary.
Then the riddles themselves involve just simple push pull mechanics, sometimes with kind of a dexterity check because you need to change polarity on the fly.
Solving the riddles feels really unrewarding. You don't feel any sense of accomplishment, just another tedious section done.

And then there is the voice acting. The indian accent gets pretty annoying after just minutes.

If you're looking for a cool innovative puzzle game, I'd recommend "Lightmatter" or "the Touring Test" but not this one.
 
mrmarcelluswallace
0

Also, if the dumpster-fire that is Twitter is still relevant enough to be referenced by someone in the year 2120, then humanity deserves what it gets.

776 produits enregistr√©s
0
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
13.9 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 8 juin 2021
Vid√©o YouTube‚Ñ¢: Relicta | A Review 
Vues : 136

This review is a truncated version based on the upper character limit for Steam reviews. For the full version, watch the video.

In essence, Relicta fits the term ‚Äúfirst-person physics puzzler‚Äù about as well as you could imagine: It‚Äôs mostly about moving blocks through levels in order to hold down buttons or transport you around. Both things are achieved by what the game calls magnetism, because apparently the cubes and plates you can operate are made of magnetic materials, but honestly, it seems more like you‚Äôre able to just manipulate gravity itself even beyond mere magnetism. I say this mostly because the main attraction/repulsion mechanic is actually expanded with a third option that allows you to cancel out downward gravity altogether in order to fling these cubes around without them falling to the ground, so both types of manipulation do similar things.

The game is overall structured in a handful of zones spanning a couple of biomes on a moon base, where each zone introduces a new obstacle in a handful of enclosed ‚Äútest chambers‚Äù that you must overcome with the use of your basic powers, which stay the same over the entire length of the game. So while at first you only have to figure out ways to traverse these levels with the aforementioned cubes and mounted plates by giving them a polarity to either attract or repel each other, later challenges introduce switch puzzles, moving platforms, shifting scenery and flying drones that cancel out any polarity you‚Äôve set, so there is a variety of interactions the game gets out of its simple mechanic.

And to the game‚Äôs credit, it never overcomplicates these additional mechanics. A trap I‚Äôve seen very often in these types of puzzle games that build up in complexity while maintaining a simple basic core of mechanics is that some think throwing in every conceivable obstacle at the player in a single level is a good idea. So it‚Äôs usually a sign of quality and that the developer really thought about the challenge curve of their game if they manage to avoid this pitfall.

However, the game falls into another pitfall that ended up frustrating me at certain parts. As the term ‚Äúphysics-puzzler‚Äù implies, the game relies on physics interactions. And one of the most important aspects of a game that relies on physics interactions as part of its core mechanics is that the physics must be predictable and repeatable. And unfortunately, that isn‚Äôt always the case. So while you can set up your blocks and plates in a way that make you think whatever you‚Äôre attempting is going to succeed, if the physics system decides to not play ball, you can sometimes lose all progress of any given test chamber through no fault of your own and you have to reset it.

While resetting is not that big of a deal in the beginning, because the challenges are all short and snappy, it can cause you to tear your hair out in later stages. Later test chambers are actually multi-stage puzzles, where in order to gather the cubes to move on to the next chamber, you‚Äôll first have to figure out how to get these cubes to the main area of the chamber in the first place. And if the physics system craps itself just before that final hurdle, you‚Äôll have to do the entire thing from the top again, which just isn‚Äôt fun. Because at that point, you‚Äôre not solving a puzzle, you‚Äôre just executing a solution. A proper save-system that saves this kind of progress would‚Äôve been very welcome during some of the later levels.

You might have noticed that I mostly focused on the gameplay aspect and haven‚Äôt mentioned the story in the slightest here. And that‚Äôs because I don‚Äôt really think there‚Äôs much to say about the story. It‚Äôs a fairly generic little tale about a moon colony getting taken over by the titular alien artifact that‚Äôs also responsible for giving you the ability to control magnetism and gravity. Most of the narrative happens over the phone because modelling, rigging and animating people is hard, so don‚Äôt expect to interact with people face to face. The story is also mostly told at you through not that great voice-acting and your character is either ordered to go somewhere to do something or decides on their own to go somewhere and do something. As it happens, ‚Äúgoing somewhere and doing something‚Äù always means passing through one of the test tracks littered with the test chambers. So in essence, the whole puzzle aspect, even though it‚Äôs initially caused by the MacGuffin du jour, has absolutely no overlap with the narrative. It even goes so far that the main character points out that everything they have to do is always on the far side of one of the test tracks that can‚Äôt be circumvented for some convenient reason, so the gameplay actively interferes with the narrative instead of complementing it.

I didn‚Äôt particularly enjoy these kinds of fourth wall breaks where the game highlights the tedium of trying to move on with whatever you‚Äôre attempting to do while constantly being roadblocked by what should be the main attraction of the game. It highlights a certain disconnect in what the game thinks people show up for, because if you include a narrative that makes fun of the gameplay it forces the player to endure and makes it seem like the most tedious aspect of the game, you might end up causing players to ask themselves why they‚Äôre even playing a game that makes fun of what players who like puzzle games show up for. And in fact it did cause me to resent the later sections of the game, because the new mechanics they introduce aren‚Äôt used in varied and novel ways, you‚Äôre just expected to solve five or six challenges that involve the same mechanics, but they almost never ask you to apply the principles you‚Äôve just learned in the first level of any given section in alternate ways in later puzzles, so they literally turn out to be roadblocks I wished I didn‚Äôt have to endure on my way to wrap up the narrative.

Between the puzzle sections, you have to walk through empty parts of the moon base that are built out of endlessly copypasted segments that all look the same. You can explore a few of the crew quarters, communal areas and laboratories, but there‚Äôs no real visual storytelling going on anywhere, it‚Äôs just a stereotypical sterile sci-fi environment. The only background lore you can pick up on is communicated through collectibles that you have to go out of your way and find. It sets up this needlessly complex backstory of how these various non-Terran colonies went through revolutions, fights for independence and how they‚Äôre currently under a not too favorable administration, which is why the team working at your base must conceal any knowledge about the Relicta seeping out from the colony.

Honestly, the game just couldn‚Äôt manage to make me give a shit about either the setting or the story it tried to tell and the story actively made me not really look forward to doing the later puzzles because my payoff would just be more badly voice-acted narrative steeped in this terribly overwrought and yet still ill-defined setting. Unfortunately, I can‚Äôt really recommend Relicta, not even to fans of physics-puzzlers. The basic gameplay is interesting and while I certainly had fun with some of the puzzles, its overall execution leaves to be desired and the narrative lives in this entirely separate world from the gameplay and it‚Äôs just not an interesting tale worth telling. I think a good indicator whether the game was worth playing is provided with the fact that the game contains two additional campaigns, one of which takes place after the narrative of the main game and I didn‚Äôt even bother playing either of the two, because I honestly had more than enough after finishing the main game.
 
Avocado Diaboli
2,273 produits enregistr√©s
0

15+ hours of mice puzzle gameplay. Lot's of interesting mechanics introduced gradually throughout the game with a nice learning curve. There is a somewhat interesting plot, although, not directly related to the gameplay. A solid recommendation.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 27 aout 2020
I don't know if I'm seeing things, but I swear every time I go though the main hub, it's just *slightly* different. Like a potted plant has changed to a different, similar plant or some similar change. And considering certain events that I won't spoil, that fits PERFECTLY!

I don't care if it's not actually happening and I'm just not noticing certain details until a later trip through, This game is perfectly playing my paranoia, without making me feel threatened! Just puzzles, no real danger. Just keep doing those tests. It's fine. Keep testing. Everything is fine. We can wait for you to finish the tests. We can wait for you to join us...

155 produits enregistr√©s
0
2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
40.9 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 17 aout 2021
IMO this is one of the better puzzlers out there. It has a surprisingly engaging plot and probably a higher quantity of puzzles than any other game I've played. The mechanics allow for a surprisingly large amount of diversity in challenges, but still some of the puzzles were repetitive and others felt like I solved them incorrectly.

I also appreciate the protagonist being an Indian female, an incredibly under-represented group (I'm pretty sure this is the only game I know of that this is the case). The scenery and environment was also absolutely beautiful.

Overall, I definitely recommend. You get a lot of game for the price, and the puzzles and plot were definitely well made and engaging. I don't consider it the best puzzle game I've ever played, but it's among the greats.
 
Kamel

√âvaluation publi√©e le 27 aout 2020
–î–æ—Å—Ç–æ–π–Ω–æ–µ –º–µ—Å—Ç–æ —Å—Ä–µ–¥–∏ –≥–æ–ª–æ–≤–æ–ª–æ–º–æ–∫ –æ—Ç –ø–µ—Ä–≤–æ–≥–æ –ª–∏—Ü–∞. –ü—Ä–æ–∑—Ä–∞—á–Ω—ã–µ —Å—Ç–µ–Ω—ã (–ø—Ä–æ –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–µ –∏–Ω–æ–≥–¥–∞ –≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä—è—Ç) —Å–æ–≤–µ—Ä—à–µ–Ω–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–ø—Ä—è–≥–∞–ª–∏ –∏ —è –ø—Ä–µ–¥–ø–æ—á—Ç—É –∏—Ö –∏ –æ—Ç–ª–∏—á–Ω—ã–π –≤–∏–¥, —á–µ–º —Å–ø–ª–æ—à–Ω—ã–µ –∑–∞–≤–∞–ª—ã, —á—Ç–æ–±—ã –Ω–µ –ø—Ä–æ–π—Ç–∏. –î–∞ –∏ —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞–Ω—ã –æ–Ω–∏ —É–º–µ—Å—Ç–Ω–æ.
–°–∞–º–∏ –≥–æ–ª–æ–≤–æ–ª–æ–º–∫–∏ –Ω–µ —Å–∏–ª—å–Ω–æ —Å–ª–æ–∂–Ω—ã–µ, –Ω–æ –≤ –∫–æ–Ω—Ü–µ –∏–≥—Ä—ã –∏ –ª–µ–≥–∫–∏–º–∏ —è –±—ã –∏—Ö —Ç–æ–∂–µ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–∑—ã–≤–∞–ª. –ì–æ–ª–æ–≤–æ–ª–æ–º–æ–∫ –º–Ω–æ–≥–æ, –∏–≥—Ä–∞ –Ω–µ –∫–æ—Ä–æ—Ç–∫–∞—è.
–£—Ä–æ–≤–Ω–∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞–Ω—ã –æ—Ç–ª–∏—á–Ω–æ, –∫–∞–∫ –∏ –≥—Ä–∞—Ñ–∏–∫–∞ –≤ —Ü–µ–ª–æ–º. –ì—É–ª—è—Ç—å –ø–æ –ª—É–Ω–Ω–æ–π –±–∞–∑–µ —Ç–æ–∂–µ –∫–ª–∞—Å—Å–Ω–æ.
–ú–æ–≥—É –ø—Ä–∏–¥—Ä–∞—Ç—å—Å—è —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –∫ –æ—Ç—Å—É—Ç—Å—Ç–≤–∏—é —Å–æ—Ö—Ä–∞–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è –≤ –ª—é–±–æ–π —Ç–æ—á–∫–µ, –Ω–æ, –Ω–∞ —É–¥–∏–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ, —Å —ç—Ç–∏–º, –Ω–∞ —Å–∞–º–æ–º –¥–µ–ª–µ, –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º –Ω–µ –±—ã–ª–æ –∞–±—Å–æ–ª—é—Ç–Ω–æ.
–°–ª–æ–≤–æ–º, —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ –≥–æ–¥–∏–∫-–¥—Ä—É–≥–æ–π, –∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏—è —Å–ª–µ–≥–∫–∞ –∑–∞–±—É–¥—É—Ç—Å—è –ø—Ä–æ–π–¥—É –∏–≥—Ä—É –µ—â–µ —Ä–∞–∑.
 
Bilir
0
3 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
27.8 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 25 aout 2020
In Relicta, you play a woman who's a scientist on the moon. In the biospheres there (ice, desert, jungle ...) she has to test her gravitational gloves which are bades on an artifact.
And that's the first minus: The tests that you play are not about the gloves, they are about your ability to solve puzzles. So that story premise makes no sense.
Next thing: something happens, she has to get from A to B. Too bad, that there are more test hindering her on the way. So the tests are presented as a nuisance to the player ...
And why the hell would you build the test in the way where you have to move from A to B without any possible way around?
This makes not a single bit of sense as other characters have moved to the place I need to go, but I'm the only one with the gravitational gloves.

That's basically the whole story. OK, there is a bit more to it. The story is only told in uninteractive dialogue after completed tests. Only at a handful of points there are short wannabe-ingame-cinematics.

Between the tests you often have to take the maglev-train. And that's where you have to walk through empty train stations. (well there are some emails & logs left to find, but that's all you can do in the train stations.

Where in portal you have the e¬¥levator, walk 5 meters and are in the next puzzle room, here you have 3 loading screens, 2 to ~5 doors to walk through, an 'enter the train' animation that has potential to annoy as a time-waster and you always have go to a table with a holographic map to set your destination.

Sometimes it feels like 50% walking to the next level and 50% playing that level.

That being said about the story - the gameplay of the puzzles is fun.

You've got the typical cubes and switches to put them on. You've got the gloves that can magnetize the cubes and certain surfaces. You've got walls for you or the cube. Sometimes you can mark a cube and then teleport it to a teleport exit. Mash all that together and you can generate many maps from that.

There is a "story walkthrough" video that is shorter than 5 hours, but that's only when you know the solutions already. I needed 20+ hours for my first playthrough.
Finding the solutions is fair. It's mostly 'see what you CAN do and do it'. New puzzle elements and their function are easily recognizable.

TL;DR: Gameplay is fun, but prepare for tedious walking between the puzzles. Forget the story.

Quality level: Magrunner.
Portal and Talos Principle are out of reach for this one.
 
Niesrind
824 produits enregistr√©s
0
2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
31.1 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 6 aout 2021
Note: This downvote is in lieu of a "middle" rating since Steam does not have those. I do not hate this game, but I have stuff to say about it.

This game reminds me of several other games in the FPP genre:
  • Portal and Portal 2: because of course. Any game where you place boxes onto pressure plates is bound to have this comparison.
  • Q.U.B.E., and in particular Q.U.B.E. 2: the Relicta ("thing") is highly reminiscent of the sentient Q.U.B.E. from said series, in addition to the player's gloves always being visible during puzzle solving. Also some of the gameplay mechanics kinda reminded me of those in the Q.U.B.E. series (mostly the magnetism mechanic).
  • The Swapper (which technically is not a first-person game, but it is a puzzle game): only slightly, but for similar reasons as above.
  • The Talos Principle: length and depth of puzzle design, as well as the puzzles taking place in (semi-)artificial natural environments.
  • The Turing Test: narrative and atmosphere. Both take place in futuristic, sci-fi-style space, with high-tech labs and whatnot. Arguably though, despite the semi-immature swearing, the narrative in Relicta comes across as more genuine and has more character than that of The Turing Test. However, overall the story of Relicta feels half-baked.
In addition, the game tries to do the two-ending-last-minute-choice thing that Q.U.B.E. 2, The Swapper, and The Turing Test all tried to do. For such a linear game with an underdeveloped narrative, it's actually... rather underwhelming. Neither of the Portal games nor Q.U.B.E. needed them to have a sufficiently satisfying ending, and The Talos Principle managed its endings quite well.

Being an Unreal Engine game, it looks pretty (well, 99% anyway). The boundary control is decent ‚Äî not too many rock walls to gate the player (like in many games), yet parts of the environments (sometimes intentionally) look contrived for the sake of gameplay. The sound design is nice ‚Äî borderline immersive even (but why are there no footstep sounds at Chandra base?). The music however, is... actually kinda lacking and samey, particularly during puzzle solving. I get it ‚Äî too dramatic, and players will feel distracted, but a little variety would be nice (either that, or omit the music entirely, like in The Witness, and parts of Portal and Portal 2).

Controls are fine ‚Äî standard Portal-style FPP controls. In fact I never really needed or used the sprint feature. The hard part for me was trying not to get my mental wires crossed when it came to the cube polarity (and remembering to switch on anti-gravity), but that was to be expected. The game feels OK to play, but if you're feeling "boxed in" or get motion sick, try disabling motion blur, head bobbing, and/or setting the field of view to at least 100.

The puzzle design is nice ‚Äî good flow (which actually makes them feel more like convolutions than puzzles), conceptually not too taxing (meaning it's fairly accessible even to non-veterans of the puzzle game genre), and even if you can't always see where to go, you can always suss it out, so in due time you won't feel too overwhelmed.

For the former half of the game, the puzzles feel clean. As the game progresses however (particularly by the second part of Sverdrup beach), it begins to look messier, and a few elements even become redundant in certain puzzles. There are lots of semi-blinding fields (similar to Portal 2's Emancipation Grills), some of which tastelessly have no border. I think the devs tried to follow a little in the footsteps of The Talos Principle in this regard; however, more complex puzzles ‚â† better or more difficult puzzles.

Relicta has "puzzle checkpointing", where you press a switch to make the puzzle more comfortable to progress through. The issue with puzzle checkpointing is that it's almost never automatic, but even with this in place, there is still a degree of softlocking, where a cube will sometimes float out of place, get stuck on some inaccessible obstacle, and force the need for a whole tedious puzzle to be reset.

The main mechanics and puzzle areas have a narrative explanation, but they're even weaker than those of The Turing Test. This creates the problem of separating out the narrative from the gameplay (granted, the narrative pacing is at least better than, say, TRI: Of Friendship and Madness). This is a problem because the puzzles in the latter half of the game feel even more like a purposeless chore (NB The Talos Principle also suffered from much the same problem ‚Äî once you get to the red sigils in that game, it can feel a little like a slog ‚Äî but at least many of the puzzles aren't overly daunting in that game).

Update: I have now finished both extras (Aegir Gig and Ice Queen). While the above exactly applies to Aegir Gig (except with a slightly more confusing story), Ice Queen is an improvement on story and music. However everything else remains the same.












Lastly, there's a voice in this game that sounds a lot like Jim Sterling doing a fake ad for Creedle & Crabnuts.
 
The Sojourner
147 produits enregistr√©s
0

It's Portal without the charming dialogue and more frustrating level design. In between levels, you get to explore a moon base that is a numerous rooms and corridors (that all look the same) and have to find random points in the base.
 
3_14_eater

1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile

Recommand√©
57.6 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 8 juillet 2022
Other reviews are already better than what I could write, so I'll just keep it short. Overall, if you like Portal or other Portal-likes, it's a reasonably fun and challenging game. It seems to run on a bit long and is a bit repetitive at times. Also, you'll find yourself solving levels without using all the magnets and stuff that were laid out, so either there are intentionally a bunch of red herrings placed throughout the game, or a lot of ways to cut corners and dodge stuff. The game usually avoids letting you get yourself trapped, but it's still possible occasionally, meaning you have to hold down R and reset all progress to redo the level up to that point. Luckily that's pretty rare.

I guess that's enough rambling. I wish some of the other Portal-likes I played were as decent as this one.
 
RevengeFromMars

√âvaluation publi√©e le 18 d√©cembre 2023
The Talos Principle. –ü—Ä–∏–Ω—Ü–∏–ø –¢–∞–ª–æ—Å–∞, –¢–∞–ª–æ—Å–∞ –ø—Ä–∏–Ω—Ü–∏–ø... –î–≤–µ —ç—Ç–∏—Ö –∑–∞–º–µ—á–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω—ã—Ö –≥–æ–ª–æ–≤–æ–ª–æ–º–∫–∏ –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –ø–æ—Ö–æ–∂–∏.

–ù–µ–æ–∂–∏–¥–∞–Ω–Ω–æ –æ–±–Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂–∏–ª–∞ –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ —Å—é–∂–µ—Ç–∞ –Ω–æ–≤—ã–µ –∫–æ–º–Ω–∞—Ç—ã –∏—Å–ø—ã—Ç–∞–Ω–∏–π, –æ—Ç–Ω–æ—Å—è—â–∏–µ—Å—è, –æ—á–µ–≤–∏–¥–Ω–æ, –∫ –¥—Ä—É–≥–æ–π –∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∏–∏.

ÏïÑÏâ¨Ïõ†Îçò Ï†êÏùÄ Í≤åÏûÑ Î∂ÑÎüâÏù¥ÎÇò Ï£ºÏ†úÏóê ÎπÑÌï¥ÏÑú ÏóîÎî©Ïù¥ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ ÎπàÏïΩÌïòÎã§Îäî Í±∞. ÏóîÎî©ÏóêÏÑúÎèÑ ÌîåÎ†àÏù¥Ïñ¥Í∞Ä Îä•ÎèôÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Î≠îÍ∞ÄÎ•º Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÍ±∞ÎÇò Ï¢Ä Îçî Í∞ïÎ†¨Ìïú Ïó∞Ï∂úÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï§¨Îã§Î©¥ Ï¢ãÏïòÏùÑ Í≤ÅÎãàÎã§.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 29 mai 2021
Excellent Cube-n-Button based physics based puzzle platformer, decent story and a large amount of puzzles that will leave you head scratching, even for someone as experienced as me. I've logged 11 hours as of this review and will continue to log many more after this review. Has a very nice difficult curve that doesn't get too difficult to quickly, but also doesn't waste your time teaching you all the super beginner puzzles. Not reccomended for starting out, see Portal / Portal 2 if you want the creme da la creme.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 15 septembre 2020
As someone who only just recently realized the PDA serves as a quest tracker and is notoriously unwilling to pay attention to any given storyline, finding my way to the respective puzzle next in line appeared to pose the biggest, as well as most tedious, challenge yet. Until I, to my own astonishment, found myself absorbed in the ongoings of Chandra, which also significantly relieved my directional confusion. Legit one of the most entertaining ingame dialogue styles I‚Äôve come across in years...can't help but love the latest addition to the crew.

+ Diversified and generally great level design
+ Original approach to the 3D puzzle theme
+ Progressive complexity
+ Amusing and captivating Story

Go get it, pronto

6.7 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 22 aout 2023
I have played, but not completed the game and don't think I will reach the end, but still I recommend it.

The reason for not finishing this game is that I personally have found that I do not enjoy first person puzzle games that much, however I will not put that as a slight against the game as from what I have played (half way through) the puzzles are good and get increasingly more complex and hard as the game goes on. I found not noticeable hikes in difficulty, but rather a steady increase in difficulty. I would also say this game is harder then Portal 1, but seems to be heading towards the difficulty of some of the later areas of Portal 2.

The story was the most enjoyable aspect of the game for me and I liked the world building and lore, it did not just exist as a backdrop or justification for the puzzles.

The Characters where enjoyable. The environments are good enough for the story and puzzles.

il faut parfois sortir de ses habitudes fonctionnelles pour s en sortir. c est souvent l√† que j ai plant√©...

√âvaluation publi√©e le 21 f√©vrier 2021
Relicta doesn't make the best of first impressions but quickly makes up for that with satisfying game play mechanics and well crafted physics.
Voice acting ranges from adequate to good and the dialogue strikes a neat balance between serious and funny.
The story/game play balance is also good, delivering portions of the story at the end of each puzzling session.

Overall, Relicta is a well made experience more than worthy of it's price tag.

4 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
16.5 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 11 aout 2020
If i can think of it, i can create it - Symetra

Relicta has filled the void in my heart that The Talos Principle left me with after i have finished the game. Finally a truely awesome Puzzlegame, mixed with an interesting setting, beautiful looks and fitting soundtracks!

But before i just overwhelm this review with praise lets look at the details and let me explain, why i like this game so much.

Setting
You play this game as a scientist who is altering gravitiy with some new future technology and uses it to overcome puzzle levels to study the limits of this technology. You are playing this on Habitats that were created on the moon itself! And if you are woundering, why a scientist should basicly play puzzlelevels...on moonhabitats, that look like Forests, Icefields or Sand Deserts...well there is a very good explanation to it!

But i dont want to spoiler it for you so only a few words: The lore in this game is really interesting. Over my lifetime i have played i guess over a thousends of games and i have to say i never saw an sci-fi universe like this before! The storys of what is going on, how the world outside of the game looks, and why there are habitats like this on the moon is really interesting and refreshingly new! I personally was just a bit sad, because since the world is so interesting i would love to learn more about it, that what you learn from the data-logs you collect on the way.

Gameplay
Now let us come to the main element of this game: The puzzles! There are in my opinion two type of puzzle games. There are those like Myst, where you have no idea what is possible and what not and you have to find the solutions in the world while not knowing what you are even supposed to do. These type of puzzle games always turned me off, since after a while i get stuck at some place and i dont have the slieghtest idea what i am supposed to do, if i should be even be here and so on. And then there are games like Portal, or The Talos Principle where you get thought very early the basic mechanic of the game and how it functions...but then the level you encounter are warping this easy concept more and more into a complex monster, where you really need all your brainpower to solve it. But even when the games can become really hard it always feels fair, since you know how the mechanics work, you just have to apply them to this new situation you are confrontet with. Relicta thanksfully fits into the 2nd kind of puzzlegame that i love so much.

Your main game mechanic is that you can charge a cube and certain fields positiv or negativ and thus make the Cube beeing pulled towards or pushed from certain object. Also you can remove the gravity from the cubes, so that if they have a certain acceleration into a direction, they can go towards it, until they hit a wall or source that pushes them into a different direction - and thats it! What sounds like a cool concept but that got figured out after a short while let me say you: No! Even after i played this game for 15 hours, the game still finds way to surprise me and force me to think of new ways how to use this mechanic to solve the later puzzles! Also i have to say: This game is hard! Especially in the later stages. But what i love about this kind of game that because you know of all the possible mechanics already early on, it is never unfair! There were points where i was to stubborn with a wrong idea how to solve a puzzle and was thinking "ohh man! This game is bugged! There is no solution" and called it a day...only to come back the next day, with a clear, fresh mind, and figured out a new method that worked this day! Moments like this really give me a great feeling of accomplishment and fun, and they make out for all the frustration, when i am stuck on a certain puzzle longer then i would like :D

Also i have to congratulate the developers for how much polishment must have went through this game! Because since its a physics game in where your cubes can basicly fly everywhere, and since it is a not to big developer studio, i was afraid that there will be many moments where i have to load a savefile because my cube got stuck on impossible locations where you cant reach it anymore, making the solution of this puzzle impossible. And ohh boy did i ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up my cube-locations many times. But there was always a clever way how i could still get my cube, or how it could never get stuck on some place where you cant reach it anymore. In general the whole game was totally free from any kind of buggs, and i was really positive surprised how well polished everything plays.

My only critique with this game are the "Angle" puzzles. As you know by now, this game is physic based, but with this cool idea sadly come certain problems. Because the physic of how, where and with which tempo the cubes move is calculated by a physic engine, the outcome can sadly greatly vary. Most of the puzzles are very methodical. If you know what to do, you will accomplish the puzzle in 100% of the times. But there are also a few puzzles where your cube has to move in a very certain angle to reach his goal without clear sides that will guaranteely push him in this direction...and in this cases you have to pray to RNG'sus that the cube will behave in the way you want to. Sometimes the cube will hit a wall, because you have misplaced your cube by one pixel to much to the left, sometimes you cube dont move at all even though it should, sometimes you make everything exactly as you should but the cube still hits a Wall to fast, and jumping to a location it never supposed to go. There were a few moments where i figured out exactly what to do, but still had to try 2-3 (in the later case even around 20 ( Yes i look at you first puzzle of the last junglemap! ) of doing the same thing over and over and hopeing that the physic "RNG" will be kinder to me this time around...what as you can imagine is extremly frustrating. But thankfully this kind of puzzles where really rare, and in most cases the difficulty only came from figuring out how to solve a puzzle and not by executing it right in terms of angles.

Story
Between solving puzzles your character talks with various characters that are also on the moonbase. This conversations are either pushing the plot forward (because you realise more and more that something is not right) or are just a welcome distraction in between puzzle levels where your character banters with the other Persons of the Station. And even though you sadly never really interact with them, it was so interesting to see how much you come to care for all the characters from their voices alone! I really have to salute all the voiceactors in this game, i found all of them spot on! There was not a single character where i didnt really had an opinion on, i either really really loved them, or found them very shady and untrustworthy. I also dont know languages enough to hear which accent most of them are talking, but it was so refreshing to hear them talk since its not the generic english that you hear in most other games. I dont know how to describe it: While most of the games i rather thing of "wow this Voiceacting sounds really really bad" or "yep thats good voiceacting, where the characters sound as i think they would sound" i cant think of a nother game where i was looking forward so much of hearing the characters talk again...just to hear their voice, and cute banter once more.

Conclusion
All in all, i think that Relicta is a fantastic puzzle game, and a true hidden gem, that sadly dont seem to get the recognition it deserves. If you like the idea of puzzle games look no further, since this is without a doubt one of the best you will find. I wish the developers all the best and cant wait for their next projects, since they really got my attention after i saw how much work was put into every detail of this game.
 
andrej

0

La mayor√≠a de los puzzles son completamente obtusos y muchas veces no est√° claro como terminar el puzzle o que hacer para seguir

1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
38.3 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 27 mai 2021
This is a good puzzle game for the price! Especially with the dlc out, there is plenty of puzzle to do. The major thing to note about this game is that it is more or less a free-form puzzle game. Unlike something like portal placing portals in set areas, you can place the cubes (the primary puzzle manipulation object in the game) wherever you want. One of the outcomes of this system is that it is not always obvious exactly what you need to do. There are some puzzle areas in the game I'm pretty sure I did incorrectly. Even if you are not looking to take shortcuts, or solve things incorrectly, the techniques the game teaches you to use look no different being used right or wrong. I myself think this is fine. There was never any time I could just skip the entire map, just got to the end in an alternative way. The only major problem is when the gameplay is set to be fast. In a game like portal, speed is a big part in many puzzles. In this game you wont be throwing cubes and catching and throwing objects. Just standing in front of a cube to pick it up can sometimes be a problem, a bit finicky. So, when the game wants some "fast" action it isn't very smooth. Luckily it seems the devs understand this limit. The game never goes past its limits, but you can feel it on some puzzle sections. A smaller problem is since you are placing the cubes anywhere, you need to align them carefully or you might shoot it off into nowhere. IT IS possible to soft lock the current puzzle you are on. It only happened to me once, but its just one of the consequence of having a very open puzzle system.

One other thing I want to mention. THE STORY, It has to be said. The story is insane, in the insane way. The voice acting is great, but the characters are also insane. Every time the story shows itself, I am being blasted with so much dramatics. The story is very consistent though, but it's like a soap opera turned up to 11, both in style and in volume. So much yelling.
 
Mon-Tee
0
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
48.6 h en tout

The graphics are good enough. The world is a bit less interactive than I expected. But it is tolerable. In general, it is a good game.

11.3 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 20 d√©cembre 2022
If you like challenging puzzle games, give Relicta a try. It will wrinkle your brain.
BUT
If you like to relax while playing puzzle games, skip Relicta. It's too complex to be relaxing.

I'm in the second category. I made it through the Tower level, then - blocked. The difficulty escalated quickly after that point. I don't know if I'm dumb or my brain just isn't wired right to complete magnet-and-gravity puzzles, but it was impossible for me to progress past the Tower without major help from guides & walkthroughs. That's not how I like to play puzzle games, so after 11 hours, quitting for now. Up to that point I enjoyed it - good graphics, good soundtrack, a surprisingly interesting story, and the puzzles were fun too.

But those advanced puzzles... Some problems that made the puzzles frustrating:
- frequently can't see where to go - ie the objective of the puzzle.
- it's not always clear what a switch or pressure pad does.

6/10 because I liked it right up to the part where it got too complicated.

Linux users: played perfectly using Proton 7.0-5 #Arch #Radeon
 
AbedsBrother
1,388 produits enregistr√©s
0
2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
12.8 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 6 aout 2021
Finished another 1st person view puzzle from my backlog... Wee!

Rather than saying this is yet another portal spawn... this one looks more like "The Turing Test" wannabe... as my review on The Turing Test said before, the game is pretty weak for a Square Enix game... so i am not sure why someone will want to follow its footsteps anyway other than the brand power of Square Enix. Anyway, this game is very similar to The Turing Test in most of the way especially in stage design and story telling part.

The puzzles of this game is no where near hard, but this turned out to be a pretty hard game. So what's making this game hard? The total randomness of some of its physic is causing a lot of trouble in the puzzle solving, and sometimes we can even solve the puzzle outside the intended solution just because the box floated and slide into a flavorable position. Yes, the box slides and floats with a momentum that's not fit for puzzle building imo... so this game ended up having more than one solution on most puzzles and we can simply cheat our way using those sliding malfuction of the puzzle design. In short, this is not a perfect puzzle design at all, pretty much a fail. And due to the sliding and floating flaws, even when we are doing the intended solution, we will find the box doesn't land on the switches in alignment most of the time. So there's no 100% fool proof solution to any of the puzzle and yeah, some even require "luck".

The story, started out pretty great and dramatic, eventhough it gives out a heavy feel of The Turing Test, which is very very linear and no side tracking, they actually pulled it off in telling a story better than The Turing Test imo... but about half way down the story, things started to change, a lot of the story seemed forced on and not very logically placed, more like just adding a detour to the story so they can link it to the puzzle solving part of the game... and pretty rough in the edges joining up the story pieces making some part of the game story feels awkward and out of place. And even though one of the ending turns out pretty nice (with the other being a predictable bad end), we don't get to meet a single living soul in this game, eventhough the protagonist (an old lady that seemingly able to survive high jumps from the puzzles) is talking to several people throughout the whole game, we don't get to meet any of them other than Laia's dead(?) body in a suit so we can't see what's "inside" anyway, we don't even get to see how the protagonist looks like in 3D, only her "profile picture" during her phone calls. Probably the devs are too lazy to make any character models...

Well... If this game only have those problems and none else, then i wouldn't have given this review a thumbs down. But what makes things worst is, this game physic engine is actually effected by our graphic settings. When we are playing a game with physical puzzle that require us to control gravity, this type of set off simply is unacceptable. For example, we can jump onto the box easier putting the setting on High, but will have difficulty jumping on the box in Highest setting. The box sliding problem varies with the settings too, when setting the graphic to low, everything seems light weighted. Not only that, the higher the setting, the more difficult to grab the box up, which is super frustrating when the box slide off our grab everytime we try to grab it, and have to repeat a few times or have to grab and turn in slow motion to avoid the box sliding off our hands. That adds to the stress in playing this game. And to top that up, this game has a very weird save system, it doesn't really save at the mini check points, and often require us to replay the game from the beginning of each stage after a continue from last play. Yeah, another fail design imo, and this can adds to the frustration if the game loads before some frustrating puzzle that you've already cleared.

And lastly, the physic coding they use in the game is very outdated.. kinda like those clumsy physic in games 20 years ago... almost can't believe this is a game released in 2020 with that type of physic. Well yeah, technically, we are supposed to be on the "Moon", but with the "terraformed" view only and the gravity is like on earth? Well, might as well "pretend" we are on the Moon then, it doesn't matter much since all we see is "Earth" in the game. If you notice the clouds (atmosphere) and water body in the game, then you might just noticed the dev never really did any research prio to their design, they just use the word terraformed to justify everything. Then why the moon anyway? Might as well just said it's on Earth. Oh yeah right... the buggy physic setting, blame it on bad terraforming! Brilliant! (roll eyes)

The only stuffs I like about this game is probably the rather beautifully made Terrarium placed all around the place in the game. The graphic is pretty since it's on the Unreal Engine afterall. But that's just it. Other than the graphic, the game is just on the average level, maybe even slightly below average. Can't recommend getting this on its full price, maybe on a large discount then you won't feel so frustrated with those lousy physics they use in game. And don't expect any mind blowing puzzles either, these are pretty easy and not very challenging at all. Those contraption puzzle games for kids probably do a way better job than this game in physic and "fun" imo. So yeah, don't give a high expectation if you wish to give this game a try. The graphic may makes it looks like a great game, but in the end, the graphic is all you've got to enjoy, the rest isn't on par. Story ain't bad, but if it's the story you are after, then my advise is, just youtube a play through and save your money and frustration.

Oh, and a little add-on here, this game isn't suitable for for kids either due to it's packed full of the F-words.

And... Nauseating alert! This game is by default set to maximum blurring and light effects which can easily cause one to feel dizzy in less than a minute's game play. There are settings in the game that allow us to turn off the effects and blurring as well as camera blobbing and other lighting stuffs but bear in mind that will cost you to end up with a slightly different physic result due to the game's physic somehow rely on graphic settings.
 
Meowish
0
3 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
27.3 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 27 aout 2021
Die Story dieses etwa 15h (Hauptspiel) langen Puzzler ist interessant und hat mir gut gefallen, aber das Design der R√§tsel und das mangelhafte Bug-Testing haben mir sp√§testens im 1. DLC "Aegir Gig" jeglichen Spa√ü vermiest.

Die R√§tsel sind teils unn√∂tig kompliziert verschachtelt, mit komplett unn√∂tigen Elementen bef√ºllt und haben immer mal wieder Stellen an denen es ohne Guide mehr als m√∂glich ist aufgrund von nicht 100% ausgereiften Mechaniken einfach h√§ngen zu bleiben, was zur Folge hat, dass man ein ganzes R√§tsel wiederholen kann.
Die Schwierigkeit der R√§tsel ist eigentlich nicht besonders hoch, wenn man mal wo h√§ngt dann nur wegen den beschriebenen unn√∂tig verschachtelten Arealen oder weil die L√∂sung einfach wieder mal erst beim 2. oder 3. Versuch klappt (trotz richtigen L√∂sungswegs).

Wem Puzzler gefallen, der findet sicher spa√üigere Alternativen deren Mechaniken besser ausgereift sind.
Dieses Spiel ist nur was f√ºr die leidensf√§higsten unter den Puzzlerfreunden wirklich einen Blick wert.
 
ST4LKER_ak47
0
2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
21.8 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 8 novembre 2020
If you liked The Talos Principle, Portal, or The Witness, this will be right up your alley. Much like The Talos Principle, Relicta offers individual puzzles in different worlds that grow in complexity as you go. The anti-gravity and magnetism mechanics, among other features, provide plenty of novel puzzles with interesting solutions.

The game also looks great, and the physics feel real, too. There is a little more plot here than is required, which I largely ignored, but it does add some flavor on top of the pure puzzles.

If you are into puzzle games like those mentions, you'll enjoy Relicta.
 
Occasus
0
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
31.4 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 8 mai 2021
A very strange puzzle game. Not for its puzzles, which are fairly rote magnetic block pushing whose occasional flashes of brilliance are marred by loose controls and inconsistent physics. The game is strange because it's half puzzle game and half walking simulator, and honestly I think it would be more fun without the puzzles. The writing is authentic and well-delivered, the worldbuilding is cliche but reasonable, and you grow to care about these characters and their interactions on this moon base. But to get more of the story, you have to go through yet another cavalcade of blocks and magnets.

Overall if you liked Portal and liked The Martian, and are down for a piece of media that's worse than either of them but is trying to be both, it's at least worth a shot.
 
Keith

1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile

tarutaru
753 produits enregistr√©s
0
2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
9.1 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 5 juin 2021
Relicta is a super linear puzzle game. It's simply going from Point A to B, from puzzle to puzzle, the corridors are just fillers. There's absolutely nothing to interact with outside of the puzzles and there are invisible walls everywhere to prevent you from exploring anywhere outside. Soon it becomes a chore rather than being fun. The earlier half of the game genuinely had good puzzles, it made me think and plan, almost made me feel clever but the other half just increases the number of hoops you have to go through just to get the cubes at the right place. For me, it went from 'This new area looks fun' to 'Let's get this over with and move on.'

I honestly can't continue playing Relicta anymore. I'm halfway through it but now I'm tired. It's not that the puzzles are hard, but it's a just complete slog to drag around cubes and it started to feel way more tedious than it needs to. I just couldn't see the point of playing the game anymore because I felt I was "working" to get the damn puzzles right. Once you reach the Tropical islands, you'll understand what I'm talking about.

The Story and Puzzles are totally disconnected, the sci-fi plot is interesting honestly but it doesn't work with puzzles: Oh a giant alien ate me? Oh I'm getting hallucinations and hearing voices? The AI has gone sentient? My daughter might be in danger? All you can do about it is solving damn puzzles that's it. See where I'm getting at?

The only reason I'm leaving a positive review is because it's an indie game and yes I did have fun even though for the short while it lasted. I even smiled from the inside when I saw that the protagonist is Indian. The voice acting is good, even though the speaker is non-native, there is no bad stereotypical Indian accent like Hollywood portrays. Though the quality of dialogue really degrades and no. of F bombs drop more & more and it felt really unnecessary. (I didn't care much but if it is something that bothers you)

Maybe I'll continue where I left someday, but for now, I almost feel like I am wasting my time behind it. If you like these type of problem solving puzzle games, the game provides huge amount of content for the price. The graphics are good as well thanks to unreal engine. Surely pick it in a sale if you are thinking about it!
 
TOMMY
1,188 produits enregistr√©s
0
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
14.0 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 26 novembre 2020
Relicta is an enjoyable puzzle platformer with some interesting mechanics and a fun story-line. The collectibles help to flesh out the world a bit, making it so you want to find them to learn that much more about this future world. The characters you interact with have unique personalities and desires, some of which are less obvious than others.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 11 aout 2020
This game is one of the few genuinely challenging puzzle games i have played in years. i was honestly expecting the game to be around the 6-8 hour mark but well, from what ive seen the game is gonna be a lot longer than that. the puzzle mechanics are super interesting, one thing i liked was how the game just tells you the basics and lets you figure the rest out. The graphics are next level! aswell as being really well optimised, the only time the game ever lags for me is during cutscenes and well, thats to be expected imo. the one thing i would ask of the devs is to add a fov slider as i find the game hard to play for extended periods with such a small one. it honestly wouldnt be hard with unreal engine but thats the only thing i would change! well done guys

Una nota di demerito va inoltre all‚Äôincredibile numero di muri invisibili presenti in Relicta, un vero e proprio orrore a 2020 inoltrato.
